Headline: Wallace is born in Nashville, TN
Pearl High School loses to Father Ryan High School
Wallace's senior season of basketball begins
Pearl High School wins the state high school basketball championship
Wallace chooses to attend and play basketball at Vanderbilt University
Wallace asked to leave the white Church of Christ
Wallace's first day of his freshman semester at Vanderbilt
Wallace and Dillard are the first black men to wear an SEC uniform as JV players
Wallace plays in JV game at Mississippi State
Wallace's mom admitted to hospital for cancer
Wallace hears Martin Luther King, Jr. and Stokely Carmichael at Impact '67
Wallace discusses black undergraduate experience with Vanderbilt administration
NCAA begins the ban on the Dunk shot
Wallace plays at Auburn, MSU, and LSU
Wallace hears Robert F. Kennedy speak at Impact '68
Wallace participates in memorial march honoring MLK, Jr.
Wallace interviewed by Sports Illustrated on black athlete experience
Wallace informs Vanderbilt administration on experience as black student and black athlete at Vanderbilt
Wallace wins "Bachelor of Ugliness" from student body
Wallace plays final match of Vanderbilt career
Wallace gives interview for newspaper on his experience as black student-athlete
Wallace plays for the Delaware Bluebombers
Wallace reports to basic training in Missouri
Wallace moves to Washington, D.C. to work for the Urban League
Wallace studies at Columbia Law School
Wallace invited to speak at Vanderbilt
Wallace employed by American University's Law School
Wallace (center) inducted into Vanderbilt Athletic Hall of Fame
Bill Derrick
Text: Coach of the Father Ryan High School basketball team that played against Wallace
Media Credit: Photo: Roman Catholic Diocese of Nashville

Headline: Clarence Wallace
Text: Wallace’s cousin who introduced him to basketball (no photo available)

Headline: Clyde Lee
Text: One of Vanderbilt's best basketball players who helped recruit Wallace and graduated the year before Wallace started school
Media Credit: Photo: Vanderbilt Athletics Hall of Fame

Headline: Jackie Akins
Text: Wallace's high school girlfriend (no photo available)

Headline: David "Big Daddy D" Lattin
Text: Introduced Wallace to a more theatrical dunk

Headline: James Lawson
Text: A teacher of nonviolent principles whose Nashville sit-ins helped Wallace see the possibility for change

Headline: J.C. Hull
Text: Wallace’s principal at Pearl High School
Media Credit: Photo: Cameron High School Alumni Association, Inc.

Headline: Perry Wallace's Parents
Text: Perry Wallace, Sr. and Hattie Wallace (both pictured left)

Headline: Pearl High School Basketball Team
Text:
Ted McClain, Tyrone Fizer, James
Douglas, Ervin Williams, Willie
Fisher, Melvin Smith, Walter Fisher,
 Joe Herbert, Tony Moorman

Headline: Roy Skinner
Text: The head coach of the Vanderbilt varsity basketball team who recruited Wallace to play at Vanderbilt (center)

Headline: Willie Brown
Text: A peer of Wallace who played on Father Ryan's basketball team (left)

Headline: Wilt Chamberlain
Text: He introduced Wallace to the dunk

Headline: Adolph Rupp
Text: University of Kentucky’s varsity basketball coach who complained about Wallace's use of dunking

Headline: Alexander Heard
Text: New chancellor of Vanderbilt who encouraged integration and racial equality on campus

Headline: Arthur Ashe
Text: Tennis player whom Wallace admired because he didn’t cause controversy as a black athlete

Headline: Beverly Asbury
Text: A Vanderbilt University Chaplain hired by Chancellor Heard to help with race relations (far right)

Headline: Bobbie Jean Perdue, Eileen Carpenter, Bedford Waters, Carolyn Bradshaw, and Morris Morgan
Text: Fellow Black Pioneers at Vanderbilt University

Headline: Bill Russell
Text: A basketball player whom Wallace admired because he spoke proudly about being black

Headline: Cassius Clay
Text: A black boxing champion known as Muhammad Ali whom Wallace admired for his athletic abilities and political activism

Headline: Godfrey Dillard
Text: Wallace’s fellow black teammate on Vanderbilt’s junior varsity basketball team

Headline: Lew Alcindor
Text: A basketball star known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar whose talent prompted a ban on dunking

Headline: Martin Luther King, Jr.
Text: Foremost Civil Rights leader who also spoke at Impact ‘67

Headline: Wallace's Roommates
Text: Paul Watermulder, Hal McClain, and David Lombard (no photo available)

Headline: Robert F. Kennedy
Text: A presidential candidate who spoke at Impact ‘68

Headline: Pete Maravich
Text: Wallace’s fellow SEC basketball player who faced extreme scrutiny

Headline: Stokely Carmichael
Text: A Civil Rights leader and Black Panther leader who spoke at Impact ‘67

Headline: Vereen Bell
Text: A Vanderbilt English professor who was an ally of black students like Wallace

Headline: Frank Sutherland
Text: The journalist who interviewed Wallace after his final game (pictured here are John Seigenthaler, Frank Sutherland and Wendell Rawls)

Headline: Bob Tallent
Text: The coach of George Washington University’s basketball team who asked Wallace to mentor his players

Headline: David Williams
Text: The vice chancellor of Vanderbilt who organized the retirement of Wallace’s basketball jersey number

Display Date: During Wallace's Time in Law School: 1972-1975
Headline: Ernest Green
Text: One of the Little Rock Nine and a role model for Wallace

Headline: Gabrielle Eugenie Wallace
Text: Wallace’s adopted daughter who has Asperger’s Syndrome (no photo available)

Display Date: During Wallace's Time in Law School: 1972-1975
Headline: Jack Greenburg
Text: One of Wallace’s law professors who worked on Brown v. Board of Education
Media Credit: Video: United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit

Headline: Jack Ramsey
Text: The coach of the professional basketball team the Philadelphia 76ers who encouraged Wallace to apply to law school

Headline: Joe Bryant
Text: A student on the basketball team Wallace coached who became a famous basketball player

Headline: Karen Smyley
Text: Wallace’s wife and a French professor (no photo available)

Headline: Leonard “Lenny” Burg
Text: Wallace’s coworker at Urban League and his roommate (no photo available)

Headline: Paul Robeson
Text: A black athlete, actor, and singer whom Wallace and Wallace’s dad admired for his political activism

Headline: Ron Brown
Text: He hired Wallace to work at Urban League

Headline: Sam Heys
Text: The journalist who initiated Wallace’s return to Vanderbilt and recognized Wallace as a pioneer

Headline: Triumph
Text: This major documentary film about Perry Wallace's life is coming soon
